posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

Second, public doesn't necessarily mean the state. There are other means of collective organisation and economic control such as councils and cooperative enterprise.

Idea of "capitalism-socialism-communism" transition is mostly Leninist and comes from experience of market economy being both inefficient at solving major issues and potent enough to crush alternative forms of economic organisation.

More on Psuedo-Dionysius:

https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/pseudo-dionysius-areopagite/

>The hierarchic treatises ... suggest that the sensible and intelligible realms are not places reached by a single being, but different kinds of beings, and that the vision of God is handed from being to being downward through the levels of the hierarchy. On the Celestial Hierarchy describes the intelligible realm as divided into nine ranks of beings: the seraphim, cherubim, thrones, dominions, powers, authorities, principalities, archangels, and angels. On the Ecclesiastical Hierarchy describes the human beings within the church as divided into eight ranks: the hierarchs or bishops, priests, deacons, monks, laity, catechumens, penitents, and the demon-possessed.

>The hierarchs, highest within the human hierarchy, contemplate the intelligible realm directly, though presumably they contemplate only its lowest level: the angels. The visible result of the hierarchs’ contemplation of the angels is the series of rites belonging to the Christian church.

>The ranks of hierarch, priest, and deacon are in charge of administering the rites ... The priests illuminate the laity, who are able to receive the intelligible truth. The hierarchs perfect, a task whose initiate seems ideally to be the monk, since Dionysius identifies the monks as leading the more perfect life of those who are not explicitly consecrated as clergy.

Sound like anything? This is basically how Catholics and Orthodox today understand the church to function, needing a series of intermediaries to access God, feeling a need to go through Mary or saints to access Christ, etc.

Spanish anti-clericalism goes way back to the 19th century at least, it wasn't invented in the 30s. They used to have a saying that "every Spaniard follows his priest with either a candle or a club." Burning churches was almost a national past time whenever there was a riot.

>>14530025
Cannabis was spread across Eurasia and into North Africa at the latest during the Bronze Age, mostly spread by indo Europeans as it is a plant with 1000 uses. Cannabis was extensively cultivated by the Romans for cloth and rope, the Roman navy literally ran on hemp rope. We have some evidence that cannabis was smoked (mostly from the Balkan region) as early as 2000 bc, and hash production in central and South Asia from around the same time. Resin would be scraped off the hands of people cleaning leaves and flowers from the hemp fibres and slightly later people realized this resin could be eaten or burned for a light intoxicating effect. Romans preferred to eat their cannabis than smoke it, with cannabis leaves and flowers being boiled in milk and butter to make “lozenges” typically served after dinner. These lozenges are still common in Marocco and Persia. Cannabis would have most likely been eaten until after the crusades when hash smoking was introduced from the levant to Europe. Cities like bologna in Italy were famous for the vast amount of hemp they produced until church prohibitions turned against in in the early modern period after smoking became widely known.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14526419
Because building material got cheaper and labor got more expensive.

In the past, when this kind of decorative architecture was more common, it was the opposite. You could get craftsmen to work for relatively cheap but getting good quality stones was hard. So if you were able to get some good building material, you would want to make the most of it and get your workers to make them as beautiful as possible.

More recently however, concrete, industrial brick production, machine mining etc. was invented. Suddenly, building material became dirt cheap. At the same time, workers had more options for employment, governments created minimum wages and safety standards that made labor more expensive. Also, cities started expanding fast, people and businesses demand buildings more quickly. So all incentives point to making cheap, less labor-intensive buildings quickly.

The only countries that still routinely make buildings mainly for aesthetics and disregard practicality are ones that still have slave tier labor forces like the Gulf States.

Once upon a time, there was a man named Joseph. Joseph had always been searching for something more in his life. He had tried various forms of self-improvement, but nothing seemed to fill the void he felt inside. One day, while walking through the park, he stumbled upon a strange looking store that sold all kinds of legal and illegal drugs. Joseph had heard of Bath Salts before and decided to give it a try.

After smoking Bath Salts, Joseph felt a sense of euphoria he had never experienced before. He felt like he was on top of the world. He smoked more and more, every day, until it became a habit. He couldn't go a day without it.

One day, while high on Bath Salts, Joseph saw something that changed his life forever. He saw an angel. The angel spoke to him, revealing that he was a new Abrahamic prophet, chosen by God to spread a new message to the world.

At first, Joseph was ecstatic. He felt like he had finally found the purpose he had been searching for. He immediately began to spread the word of his new religion, claiming that he was the new prophet. He preached on street corners, in parks, and anywhere else he could find an audience.

Many people initially dismissed Joseph as a drug-addicted lunatic, but as time went on, more and more people began to take notice of his message. They were drawn in by the passion and conviction in his voice and they saw the changes it brought in the lives of those who followed his teachings.

Joseph's message spread rapidly, and soon it had millions of followers all over the world. He attracted the attention of politicians, celebrities, and religious leaders. His followers built temples and churches in his honor, and his teachings became the basis for a new world religion.

From the pentecostals of georgia speaking in tongues to the guadalupan pilgrims crawling on their knees for penance, it seems we americans become the most religious when feeling strong emotions like guilt or excitement. When people here open up their religion they usually do so when they feel a strong emotion that is justified or guided by some religious ritual, with wich they invite you to participate. It's pretty much a norm that after disasters everyone from tierra del fuego to alaska prays, and churches that are usually desolate become suddenly crowded during festivities.

Even in movies and media from the united states, we see that when a character becomes insane, depressed, joyous, scared or otherwise emotionally seized, he suddenly begins to speak of religion either "guided" or "repulsed" by it.

So far i don't understand precisely what made this cultural behaviour so starkly present in the americas, but what do you think causes it?

Wrong.

Manuscript evidence is hard, physical evidence. Factual evidence, if you prefer. The video discusses this evidence at length. And much other evidence as well.

If you watched the videos, you would know this.

Now, a separate question is how one assesses the evidence. Evidence can't speak for itself; it is always subject to interpretation.

Consider the OJ Simpson case.

Blood spatters that matched the DNA of Nicole Simpson were found in OJ Simpson's house.

No one disputed that it was Nicole Simpson's blood. But the prosecution and the defense explained the blood evidence in different ways.

From the prosecution's perspective, the blood had been tracked into the house by OJ, following his brutal murder of his ex-wife. But the defense said no. Rather, they argued, the blood evidence in OJ's house was evidence that the police had tampered and conspired to convict OJ by *planting* the evidence.

Now, there are people who radically discount the evidence of the resurrection, rather like OJ's defense lawyers. They say the evidence is all meaningless, it's nonsense; a product of a delusion or a conspiracy, or a gnostic myth, if you prefer.

But the evidence remains, and a straightforward, *very* strong case can be made that the evidence in fact supports that conclusion that Christ was resurrected. That is the argument that is laid out in the videos.

It entirely depends on what you're talking about. Are we talking ethics? I mostly agree with Anscombe and her criticism of consequentialism, but I take some other ideas from, for instance, Singer even though he was a consequentialist. Are we talking epistemology? I'd say elements of Hume's work are fairly uncontroversial. Another example of something I'd agree with is Kant's Copernican Revolution, which is in a way a criticism of Hume (dogmatic slumber and all). Are we talking ontology? I lean towards the Frege-Russell-Wittgenstein tradition, but I'm honestly not well read enough in this regard to make any large commitments. Formal ontology specifically is something I'd like to dive into eventually, but regardless, I think the important part here is that I more or less agree with Wittgenstein re: metaphysics.
So yeah I get that it's easy for an A-T to easily tie all his stances to two philosophers, but it's not so simple for the rest of us.

>>14528150
Professor Eva von Dassow concurs with the presence of Indo-Aryan terms in Mitanni vocabulary, but cautiously advises against the notion of an "Indo-Aryan takeover".[2] Michael Witzel argues for the antiquity of the Indo-Aryan words attested in the Mitanni data, since they seem to predate linguistic developments attested in the Rigveda.[3]

In a treaty between the Hittites and Mitanni (between Suppiluliuma and Shattiwaza, c. 1380 BC), the deities Mitra, Varuna, Indra, and Nasatya (Ashvins) are invoked. Kikkuli's horse training text (circa 1400 BC) includes technical terms such as aika (Vedic Sanskrit eka, one), tera (tri, three), panza (pañca, five), satta (sapta, seven), na (nava, nine), vartana (vartana, round). The numeral aika "one" is of particular importance because it places the superstrate in the vicinity of Indo-Aryan proper (Vedic Sanskrit eka, with regular contraction of /ai/ to [eː]) as opposed to Indo-Iranian or early Iranian (which has *aiva; compare Vedic eva "only") in general.[4]

Another text has babru(-nnu) (babhru, brown), parita(-nnu) (palita, grey), and pinkara(-nnu) (pingala, red) for horse colours. Their chief festival was the celebration of the solstice (vishuva) which was common in most cultures in the ancient world.

The Mitanni warriors were called marya (Hurrian: maria-nnu), the term for '(young) warrior' in Sanskrit as well,[5] formed by adding the Hurrian suffix -nnu;[6] note 'mišta-nnu' (= miẓḍha,~ Sanskrit mīḍha) "payment (for catching a fugitive)".[7]

>Georges Henri Joseph Édouard Lemaître (/ləˈmɛtrə/ lə-MET-rə; French: [ʒɔʁʒ ləmɛːtʁ] (listen); 17 July 1894 – 20 June 1966) was a Belgian Catholic priest, theoretical physicist, mathematician, astronomer, and professor of physics at the Catholic University of Louvain.[1] He was the first to theorize that the recession of nearby galaxies can be explained by an expanding universe,[2] which was observationally confirmed soon afterwards by Edwin Hubble.[3][4] He first derived "Hubble's law", now called the Hubble–Lemaître law by the IAU,[5][6] and published the first estimation of the Hubble constant in 1927, two years before Hubble's article.[7][8][3][4] Lemaître also proposed the "Big Bang theory" of the origin of the universe, calling it the "hypothesis of the primeval atom",[9] and later calling it "the beginning of the world".[10]

posts.com: My theme in this, and the following chapter, is the history of this process of innocent ritualisation in Scotland: the process whereby the customs and costumes of the Scottish Highlanders, previously despised as barbarous, and at one time formally extinguished, were resumed, elaborated and extended. Thus, today, the kilt and the tartan are regarded as the traditional dress of historic Scotland: Lowland Scots imagine themselves as members of‘ clans’, and visitors from England are welcomed by the noise of bagpipes, and must struggle to read road signs in Irish lettering. The process was the work of a well-defined era: the century from 1745 to 1845. Before 1745, the Highlanders and all their customs were disownedand despised by every articulate Scotchman. After 1845 the Highland takeover was complete. The voice of protest, and of historical truth, was often raised; but it was always powerless. Romanticism might lose its power; but then tourism and commercialism would take over its legacy, extending and vulgarising it in detail. Today it is fixed in the elaborate rituals of Scots abroad, and in the well-stocked souvenir shops of Lowland Scotland.

That is significantly higher R1a than you'll find in most of the rest of the British Isles. So in many ways people in Scotland are closer in Y-DNA breakdown to neighboring Germanic peoples than the rest of the British Isles are.
Also around half of Scotland's R1b-L151 is the Germanic subclade of U106, fairly similar to the R1b-L151 breakdown in England.

I think people in Scotland generally cluster slightly closer to Scandinavians in PCAs than most of the rest of the British Isles does too (albeit it's marginally as all of the British Isles clusters incredibly closely with Scandinavians in PCAs).

So applying the Celtic label to the "Scottish" of all people in the British Isles is beyond preposterous.
Almost no Celtic language ability and the closest to Scandinavians in terms of Y-DNA and autosomal genetic clustering.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Celtic economy was very socialist, there was no need for cities because they redistributed earnings throughout the tribe, even though tribal "nobles" existed. There was no need for cities. Even though there was private property, it was at heart a distributivist system with a gift economy and tribal council level decision making.

Germanics also didn't need urban settlements because they also had a land distribution system. With families scattered around but coming together for work.

As you can tell Germanics, and Celts had many things in common with native American tribes in terms of social structure. Tribes rarely form urban settlements, and when they do its only when they form large federations and use them for religious/political reasons.

posts.name: Jackson Hinkle
posts.com:
The concept of worker ownership of the means of production is rooted in the fundamental principle of labor exploitation and the exploitation of surplus value. In a capitalist system, the means of production, such as factories and tools, are owned by a small group of individuals who are able to extract surplus value from the labor of the working class. This results in a situation where the workers, who are the creators of all wealth, are not able to fully participate in the fruits of their labor.

On the other hand, worker ownership of the means of production would allow the workers to collectively control the process of production and distribution, leading to a more equitable distribution of wealth. It would also lead to the elimination of the profit motive, which is the driving force behind the exploitation of labor.

However, it should be noted that this idea is not without its complexities and potential pitfalls. One potential problem is the potential for the emergence of a new class of managers, who would have control over the means of production and could potentially exploit the labor of others. Additionally, there is the question of how to effectively manage and organize a system of worker ownership on a large scale.

In conclusion, while worker ownership of the means of production presents a viable alternative to the current capitalist system, it is important to consider the potential complexities and challenges that must be overcome in order to fully realize this idea.
On the other hand, worker ownership of the means of production would allow the workers to collectively control the process of production and distribution, leading to a more equitable distribution of wealth. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Fun fact:

Until the first proper Census of India conducted by the British Government in 1865, most Pajeets thought that Muslims had always been the majority in India and that India was basically a "Muslim country" like Persia or Turkey.

A good example of this is how the Mughal Emperor was regarded as the "True Emperor of Hindostan" by both Muslims and Hindus - even the Marathas at their height recognized the Mughal Emperor in Delhi as 'de jure' ruler of India and addressed him as "Lord Father" (legally speaking, the Marathas were feudal vassals of the Mughal Emperor, despite being more powerful than him towards the end of the 18th century - a situation not unlike Sengoku Japan).

Another good example is how during the 1857 Indian Sepoy Mutiny, the Hindu Pajeet mutineers wanted to replace British rule with Mughal rule, going so far as to barge into the Mughal Emperor's chambers and force him to accept leadership of the rebellion as the legitimate ruler of India.

When the results of the Census showed that it was basically a small Muslim minority ruling over a vast horde of native Pajeets, a great sense of national shame and humiliation overtook the native Pajeets. This was essentially what kickstarted the Hindu nationalist movement in the 19th century.

As Reddit cringe as it may sound he may actually have a point.
All successful media is just a retelling of ancient stories, that invoke primal invoked feelings.
Feelings and situations often archetypal in nature that are ingrained within lore, myth, story, nursery rhyme and religion that can be relayed to a global audience through implanted memories alone.
Ask yourself why capeshit, Lord of the rangs, Hairy pooper, and Onions wars are as popular as they are, despite being relatively simple boring surface level tropes we've heard a thousand times before.

>All above feature a clear and distinct separation between good and evil
>All feature concise characters that embody one of the 12 archetypes think trickster, caregiver, ruler sage etc
>All feature a hero's journey and their path to self actualisation
>All feature inevitable tragedy albeit death, setback, temptation toward evil and the eventual overcoming of it
>All feature characters with a clear starting moral alignment
>All feature edgelord villains who are just plain evil
>All feature redeemed neutrals or villains who have a change of heart
>All feature a forbidden taboo romance arc
>All feature a love triangle dynamic
>All feature a David and Goliath dynamic
>All feature comic relief characters
>All feature great battles to the onset of a war
>All feature a warrior woman dynamic
>All feature legendary weapons, armour or horses
>All feature 2 face off duels one where the hero loses and escapes and a second where he wins
>All feature a happy ending with a reuniting party

Knowing this there is legitimately no reason you or me couldn't become a masterful director or writer. All it takes is to study ancient texts, plagiarise that shit to high heaven and then whack a fresh veneer on top and your done.

>2 Now after Jesus was born in Bethlehem of Judea in the days of Herod the king, behold, [a]wise men from the East came to Jerusalem, 2 saying, “Where is He who has been born King of the Jews? For we have seen His star in the East and have come to worship Him.”

Kepler believed in some aspects of astrology, the influence of the planets for example. He deduced this front his ideas about physics. He neglected other aspects of astrology. e.g. the significance of the zodiac. In 1604 Kepler observed a new star and believed in a connection to a special and very rare planetary conjunction. After a Jupiter-Saturn-conjunction Jupiter met Mars. Kepler speculated that the star of Bethlehem might be a new star which was generated after a similar conjunction and recalculated it for 6/7 BC. Nowadays examples of both astronomical (and astrological) interpretations of the star of Bethlehem exist. The best known is the three time conjunction of 6/7 BC. But the interpretation of Martin (1980) for 213 BC seems equally excellent. Vardaman (1989) takes the Halley comet of 12 BC to be the star of Bethlehem. Other speculations arise from two Novae in the years 5 and 4 BC, tabulated in sources from the Far East. But historians tell us that there is no need fo a real star. The text in Matthew, book 2 is a legend. What is important in regard to the understanding of the star of Bethlehem is the "sidus Julium" the comet which could be seen in the sky during Caesar's funeral and the match of the King of Armenia Tiridates to Nero in Rome during. There was no real star over Bethlehem. All we have are interesting speculations, like those by Kepler.

>can you elaborate on what this means?
don't overthink it. things like time and place can affect or enhance any experience from a certain perspective and alter a person's psyche and it can all happen at once and at the same time and even over the course of history. consider a simple example such as a wedding proposal in a restaurant. we might all think that to be a silly place to propose in front of everyone as we think about it now but if we were standing there before them in person we might crack a smile and perhaps clap as we witness the joy on the faces of the couple. or we may still think it's silly while at the same time not understanding that this was the location of the couple's first date when they were young and though it was corny to others it was deeply meaningful to them. or we may not see the old woman in the corner by herself shedding a small tear affected by the memory of the time with her husband who had just passed away from cancer. we may not know that a man at another table just found out his wife was cheating on him and wanted a divorce or the waitress who would find out in the morning that she was cast in the role she dreamed about when she was a girl or the bartender who is about to find out the one night stand he went home with on independence day is almost seven months pregnant with his son. and it can all change our perspective if i tell you that i'm describing or that you're watching an old home movie of something that happened in a restaurant in downtown Kansas City, Missouri in 1957. the point is that God is always speaking to us, anon. it's us who have to listen. and it's often the most meaningful and momentous events in our lives when we experience our greatest wonder and awe and humility and deference to our place in the grand scheme of things and it's often then when we, ourselves, finally do our best to stop and hear/read God.

The final authority, established by Christ, is the teaching Church, which history attests is the Catholic Church.

During his earthly ministry, Christ was the Final Authority. His authority superseded the Old Testament, human reason, Jewish Tradition, and the power of the state.

Jesus told his disciples, “All power in heaven and on earth has been given to me. Go, therefore, and make disciples of all nations . . . teaching them to observe all that I have commanded you. And behold, I am with you always, until the end of the age.” (Matt. 28:18-20)

- “As the Father has sent me, so I send you.” (John 20:21)

- “Whoever listens to you listens to me. Whoever rejects you rejects me. And whoever rejects me rejects the one who sent me.” (Luke 10:16)

- “Whatever you bind on earth shall be bound in heaven, and whatever you loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven.” (Matt. 16:18; Matt. 18:18)

The Thessalonians, obviously. They, like the Bereans, examined the Scriptures with Paul in the synagogue, yet they rejected his teaching. They rejected the new teaching, deciding after three weeks of deliberation that Paul’s word contradicted the Torah.

No.

Their open-minded willingness to listen was the primary reason they are referred to as noble-minded—not that they searched the Scriptures.

The Thessalonians (who rejected Paul) were the party of sola scriptura, while the Berean Jews were willing to interpret scripture in the light of Paul's preaching: "for they received the word with all eagerness." Acts 17:10.

>>14527856
1. The Scriptures are inspired by God ("All Scripture is given by inspiration of God," 2 Tim. 3:16). In Greek the term "inspiration" is "θεόπνευστος" which means literally "God-breathed." So Scripture is breathed out by God. This is what it is in its nature. It is Scripture because God breathed it out, not because someone says that it is.

2. The duty of the church in this matter is therefore to recognize and receive Scripture. It does not take a text that is neutral and then make it Scripture somehow. As I said, Scripture is Scripture by its divine nature, irrespective of anything else.

3. The Scriptures were indeed recognized by their recipient, the Church. However, simply stating that this was the Catholic Church is incorrect. The sort of divisions that exist today did not exist in that early time period, and there are multiple churches in the world who all claim to be the unique successor of the early church: the Catholic Church, the Eastern Orthodox Church, the Oriental Orthodox Church, etc.

4. Classical Protestantism (Reformed, Lutheran, Anglican) can claim this period as well, as they trace their ordinations back through the Catholic Church, and operate within the catholic tradition. The Reformation was a reform movement to fix false accretions which had entered into the church over time and had reached a critical point in the medieval era. The Reformers did not create a new church out of thin air that has no roots in anything that came before it.

5. The proliferation of strange groups under the label "Protestant" that you see today are not proper heirs of the Reformation. They do not hold to the principles of the Reformation and they do not situate themselves within the catholic tradition. Classical Protestantism receives what was handed down to us and fixes it, it does not start over and recreate Christianity from scratch.

>Do you have any good resources on the Reformed faith?
There are two streams of Reformed theology, 1) coming from England and Scotland, which is called Presbyterianism, and 2) coming from continental Europe, which is normally just called Reformed. There are not any substantial differences and they are in communion with each other.

Presbyterian Churches hold to the Westminster Standards (Westminster Confession, Larger Catechism, Shorter Catechism), which you can read here, and are a good starting point:
https://www.opc.org/confessions.html
You can find a listing of all the orthodox Presbyterian and Reformed denominations in North America here (disregard if you live elsewhere):
https://www.naparc.org/directories-2/
A decent introductory book is "What Is Reformed Theology?" by R.C. Sproul.

>Can you recommend anything specific that complies these changes?
One of the most egregious ones is the veneration of images. All of the earliest fathers condemn the practice as pagan and it does not enter the church in any meaningful way until the 6th century. There is actually zero patristic support for the practice before that time. Here's a good video on the subject by a Protestant minister with a PhD in historical theology (his channel is a goldmine really and videos on a number of similar subjects):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_ytYX4dXpRo

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14530488
>Sheol
Sheol literally means the grave.

>Gehenna
This is a reference to the valley of Hinnom, it's an actual valley that was right outside of Jerusalem historically. It isn't referenced in relation to an afterlife in the OT. The only reference to it is as a place where child sacrifice was taking place.

The connection to an afterlife comes from the Matthew 5 (the NT, not OT obviously) where Jesus uses the place where trash was burned at the time as a metaphor for the destruction of evil souls after death. Gehenna never was a reference directly to hell, only an analogy for it in the NT.

But it is wrong also to say that the OT never mentions an afterlife. Samuel is summoned by the witch of Endor to talk to Saul for example. The biblical authors disaproved of this, but people seem to have believed rituals and sacrifices to ancestral spirits and dead relatives would bring them blessings. That requires a sort of afterlife, probably similar to the greeks and mesopotamians.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14528983

In general during this period, while the notion of mass producing tanks and planes of inferior quality was an effective strategy for a few years, it simply could not be sustained with manpower losses, because while producing hardware like tanks and planes is simple and quick, recruiting and training men with the sort of skill required to handle even simple equipment was a significantly more lengthy process. As was shown in the case of Germany and Japan, while they were in fact capable of continuing to put out more then enough military hardware to meet their needs, they were chronically short of the experienced crews required to man them. Germany had lost many of its best pilots trying to defend its skies, while Japan lost all of its finest Carrier aircraft pilots either at Midway or during the Solomon Islands campaign; while both nations were able to make good their losses of aircraft, they simply could never train pilots with the sort of skill to match their predecessors in a short time. So the lesson that could be learned from this is that while machines are expendable, the men who know how to use those machines are not. America, Russia, and Britain were quick to learn this lesson upon taking stock of their losses after WWII and realized that while quantity over quality had managed to win them the war, it had left them severely weakened with significantly lowered reserves of trained crews at the end of WWII.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14522461
Your Goal A is partially correct. The Germans did desire that no military power west of the Urals exist but Germany. But the part of about driving as many Slavs past the Urals as possible is only incorrect. The plan to deport 30 million Slavs beyond the Urals was drawn up by the RSHA and the idea was so discredited (as we know from Erhard Wetzel's memoranda) that they were unofficially cast aside in the discussion of Germanization, not just in the east but also in places like Slovenia and Bohemia. We have the Generalplan Ost that followed, it doesn't call for deportation but rather limited colonization of very specific sites.
>Without resorting to cannibalism
Fears of having to resort to cannibalism had nothing to do with it. National Socialist geopolitics were influenced by Mckinder's 'Heartland Theory' and by the examples set by their rival empires. They believed that in order to contest the might of continental sized adversaries like the USA, they needed access to a massive territorial base that would act as an exclusive market for Germany, making it both self-sufficient in the absolute basic necessities of life, especially food and essential raw materials, blockade proof and unable to be starved into submission as it was in WWI, economically capable of competing with the USA (which would have been augmented as a result of European economic integration as part of Walter Funk's 'European Economic Community' (basically a Nazi EU) and basically of a size that allowed it to more efficiently project power. If you really think about it, most Nazi geopolitical aims were really just expanding on the aims of the Imperial government that preceded it. The Nazi EEC is the equivalent to Imperial Germany's Mitteleuropa concept, with the same ostensible goals.

It is hard to think that the germans would immediately begin a program of mass extermination without any replacement demographic in such a vast amount of land. we're talking a native population of nearly 4 times thats larger than that of Germany was going to be replaced in a short timeframe. The end goal was to reap the profit of the production from these lands which you definetly will not achive if you begin killing all its inhabitants.

Experiments in autonomy and limited self-governance under German tutelage were already present throughout the occupied territories. The Baltic states retained most of their pre-Soviet political infrastructure within Ostland and enjoyed varying amounts of autonomy. Hitler himself said that he foresaw the Ukraine becoming a protectorate in twenty or so years following the war. Kaukasus was already slated to become a sort of confederacy of the various peoples of the region who enjoy autonomy so long as the flow of oil was ensured.
